post.subject: Re: slide no 7: about Minimum variance control
post.message: What you say is correct, but this is an extreme situation.  In any case, the minimum variance control does not have any facility to reduce the control effort.  It is not the question of which model to use - model choice is decided by other considerations.  But once a model is given, one has to select the control technique to use.  As minimum variance control has a problem, you have to try other methods.

post.subject: Re: slide No 8: is MVC and GPC are to find optimisation goal functions for controllers
post.message: MVC is used as a reference.  No controller can get a better performance.  Unfortunately, however, MVC cannot be used in real practise.  All controller performance is generally compared with that of MVC.

post.subject: Re: Slide 3: ARMAX vs ARIMAX
post.message: It depends on whether the noise is "random" or whether it has random "steps".

post.subject: Re: slide 7: GPC vs LQG
post.message:
These are rigorous, because these do not make the approximation that GMVC makes. 

In LQG there is only one model that is used.  For example, fix the model, calculate the control law and apply it.  In GPC, it is possible to change the model with time, based on recently obtained data.  The model predictive controllers are said to be effective when plant varies with time.  If the model does not vary much and if you want to minimise the calculations, you should go for LQG.

post.subject: Re: slide 20: Determination of N
post.message: Most of the time, G will be a tall matrix.  Let us see how.  What does N depend on?  It depends on the time over which the model has an effect.  The model may have only a few parameters, but may affect the output for long times.  It follows that G will be tall.

post.message:
GMVC is easy to design and use, although approximate.  It is used by the Japanese in self tuning controllers, for example.  But this controller is only approximate.

I have given a comparison of GPC vs. LQG in another question, asked by Lalwani Aditya Ajit.  Please see it.

post.subject: Re: slide no 7: about Minimum variance control - class discussion
post.message:
There is no control problem where the cost of control effort is not a concern. MVC may demand large control effort such that the controller is not implementable.

example: assume an air conditioning system where the set point temperature has to be achieved quickly, the control effort may demand the application of 1 million ton cold air within 1ns - which will be prohibitive, cost wise. MVC is not a suitble choice for such requirements.

MVC contollers are not used in a plant.

GPC based controllers will be discussed in subsequent classes.

post.subject: Re: slide 7: GPC vs LQG - class discussion
post.message: The approximate method used to find solution for GMVC is to to differentiate the argument of the expectation (operator) withe respect to u(n). Such approximations are not used GPC ,LQG hence they are more accurate

post.subject: Re: slide 10 Value of N - class discussion
post.message:
A y = B u ................(1)

y = B/A u .................(2)

These two expressions are equivalent. However in eqn (2) long division of B by A can result in large no: of terms. For system identification requirements eqn(2) is better though computational requirements are high.The no:of terms is a trade off between accuracy and computational constraints. Similar logic is applied in selecting N value for GPC.
